Below is the usual end-of-month summary of returns for major asset classes and assets.
August was a relatively good, albeit bumpy, month for investors overall, thereby extending the year-to-date gains in many markets.
Stocks led the pack, particularly China, the Dow, and Japan. Gold also saw notable gains.
Of the items covered, only Bitcoin and oil registered negative returns for the month.

Every meeting should be aimed at achieving someone's goals; that person is the one responsible for the meeting and decides what they want to get out of it and how they will do so. Meetings without someone clearly responsible run a high risk of being directionless and unproductive. #principleoftheday

It‚Äôs important not to let our biases stand in the way of our objectivity. To get good results, we need to be analytical rather than emotional.

Whenever I observe something in nature that I (or mankind) think is wrong, I assume that I‚Äôm wrong and try to figure out why what nature is doing makes sense. That has taught me a lot. It has changed my thinking about 1) what‚Äôs good and what‚Äôs bad, 2) what my purpose in life is, and 3) what I should do when faced with my most important choices. #principleoftheday

Well‚Ä¶ is it good for someone with no experience in allocating capital to suddenly be put in charge of allocating billions?

Also, it‚Äôs not clear that career politicians actually have less in the way of conflicts-of-interest than businessmen. Career politicos have many interest groups to propitiate.

Let me address this point, as it is important.

(1) The Chinese system is run like a giant corporation. You have to run a 30k person township before you can govern a 500k person county before you manage a 5M person prefecture. Each level up becomes more competitive, and promotion requires a combination of numerical results plus political standing within the party.

(2) So, in China, you‚Äôd never go rapidly from a civilian role to high office, like Obama or Trump. You‚Äôd have to work your way up. On the other hand, the American system has the theoretical advantage of generating out-of-left-field leaders, which is hard for the Chinese system.

(3) Now, the Internet system combines aspects of both the Chinese and American system. Like the Chinese system, there is a tiered, promotional ladder based in large part on numerical results. We call it seed round, Series A, Series B, and so on! However, unlike the Chinese system, the Internet system can rapidly advance talent from all around the world, without the need to conform and pay party dues for years. Moreover, you can bootstrap and rise almost entirely outside the formal system.

(4) I am skeptical that the non-quantitative American system can generate the political leaders capable of competing with the Chinese system. For decades, innumerate US politicians have just been completely out-executed in the physical world by Chinese political leaders who are just much more technical than they are (as @danwwang ‚Äòs recent book also points out). And as the American electoral process tilts ever more towards charismatic social media presence, and ever less towards dispassionate execution-oriented mindsets, the trendlines aren‚Äôt in the right direction.

(5) However, I think the Internet system has already proven itself capable of generating economic leaders who can compete with (and outcompete, in many cases) their Chinese economic counterparts.

(6) The question is whether the Internet system can also generate political leaders capable of (peacefully) competing with Chinese political leadership, for some definition of competing. For example: can we use the Internet to create not just new companies but new cities, competitive with the best Chinese cities? We‚Äôll see. This is the long-term project of startup societies and network states.

POLITICAL BILLIONAIRES

The clip below is a good encapsulation of what modern China is by Eric X. Li, who‚Äôs one of the most thoughtful Chinese nationalists.

I appreciate his description, because the Internet is the exact opposite. Because on the Internet, capital (in the form of Bitcoin, and more generally smart contracts) really does stand above any given state.

The negative way of framing this emerging reality is that Internet capitalists are now above national governments. The positive way of framing it is: anyone can become an Internet capitalist, and there is now truly global rule-of-code that no state can easily abrogate. Moreover, individuals can‚Äôt have their digital rights revoked even by powerful states.

As for whether it‚Äôs bad if ‚Äúbillionaires‚Äù have influence over the government‚Ä¶the reality is that political leaders control many billions in assets. For example, a city like SF with ~$16B in annual budget and 11 supervisors plus a mayor essentially has 12 political billionaires.

Each of these political billionaires allocates $1B+ per year in cash, on average. This is orders of magnitude more than a typical tech billionaire allocates. That‚Äôs because tech billionaires might have $1B in net worth but perhaps only $10-50M liquid.

So: market billionaires actually have far less in the way of financial resources than political billionaires. A market billionaire might allocate perhaps $100M over the course of their lifetime, whereas a political billionaire will allocate $1B+ in a single year. This is a >100X differential.

Now, yes, it‚Äôs true that political billionaires have less for personal consumption than market billionaires do, but that is (almost by definition) societally unimportant. A political billionaire spending a billion on government worker salaries does a lot more to steer the world than a pair of fancy shoes.

One might also argue that political budgets are less discretionary than market budgets, and I‚Äôd agree, but the sheer scale of public budgets makes up for it. Even if only 1% of a $16B city budget is discretionary, that‚Äôs $160M in discretionary cash per year.

Anyway, the point is that anyone in control of a giant public budget is already in full billionaire mode. They are allocating billions in capital, so they are political billionaires. You are going to have billionaire-run government in this sense no matter what.

Because fragmented liquidity is their business model, says @wagmiAlexander üå∂Ô∏è

Just finished watching podcast by @LukeYoungblood, @wagmiAlexander & @laurashin 

And honestly I've found lots of alpha there

You can watch the full version on @Unchained_pod 
But here is short recap for you:

- Coinbase and Base are playing the long game
They're not building for next month, they're focusing on next 10 years.

- Fragmented liquidity isn't a problem
Uniswap and other protocols may seem scattered, but that's actually part of the system. It allows better distribution and makes DeFi stronger overall

- More faster and better chains are coming
Sending money onchain will be just as fast as sending message. DeFi will make it real

- Governance and incentives are evolving
Instead of rewards going mostly to insiders, new top DeFi protocols like @AerodromeFi and @MoonwellDeFi 

- Bear markets are the best opportunities for builders
The best projects are built in downturns

In total, DeFi is evolving
And you should play in long term here
